01-Introduction.name: 01-Introduction
01-Introduction.text:
New York Surrogate's Court

Small Estate Affidavit

DIY Form

Welcome! These questions will help you fill out the Small Estate Affidavit.

Use the Small Estate Affidavit to ask the Surrogate's Court for the authority to keep or give away the property of someone who died.
01-Introduction.help:
New York State DIY Forms are provided by the New York State Courts Access to Justice Program. This Small Estate Affidavit Program was created through a partnership between the New York state courts and the civil justice community. It is here to help you complete the forms you need for court online in an easy and correct way.

This interview was produced using the A2J Author Software from Chicago-Kent College of Law and is hosted on the National Public Automated Documents Online server. Lexis Nexis generously donated licensing for its HotDocs Server software.

Major funding was provided by the New York State Unified Court System and a Technology Initiative Grant from Legal Services Corporation and the State Justice Institute.

NY-DIY (Version 20090602)

06-Other application.name: 06-Other application
06-Other application.text:
In the Affidavit, you will have to swear that no one else has already filed papers to handle %%[Decedent first name TE]%%'s property and debts.

Has anyone else already filed papers to distribute the property of %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%?
06-Other application.learn: How do I know if someone else filed?
06-Other application.help:
Ask the court clerk about how to find papers that have already been filed.

Examples of the papers people file with the court in cases like yours are called "Voluntary Administration", "Petition for Administration" or "Petition for Probate of a Will."

08-Decedent domicile.name: 08-Decedent domicile
08-Decedent domicile.text: What was %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s last home address?
08-Decedent domicile.learn: What if the deceased moved to a nursing home and died there after selling the house?
08-Decedent domicile.help:
According to the law, %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s domicile is a fixed, permanent and principal home to which %%HESHE([Decedent gender])%% always intends to return.

Nursing homes are usually the place that someone only enters if %%HESHE([Decedent gender])%% is incapacitated or incompetent, and %%HESHE([Decedent gender])%% would always prefer to return home.

Therefore, %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s domicile is %%[decedent his/her TE]%% last known address before entering into the nursing home, even if %%HESHE([Decedent gender])%% no longer owns or rents the residence.

07b-Your relationship to the decedent.codeAfter:
IF [Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Wife"
SET [Client is distributee spouse TF] TO "true"
SET [Client is distributee TF] TO "true"
END IF

IF [Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Daughter"
SET [Client is distributee TF] TO "true"
END IF

IF [Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Other"
GOTO "07d-Other relationship to the decedent"
END IF

IF [Client relationship to decedent MC] <> "Other"
GOTO "08a-Confirm your relationship"
END IF

05-Your phone number.name: 05-Your phone number
05-Your phone number.text: What is your telephone number where you can be reached during the day?
05-Your phone number.learn: Why do you need my phone number?
05-Your phone number.help:
You do not have to give us your phone number if you do not want to but, it is helpful to have this information. We might want to contact you if we have questions for you.

Your telephone number will be printed on the small estate affidavit unless you check the checkbox.

01a-Voluntary Administrator Checklist.name: 01a-Voluntary Administrator Checklist
01a-Voluntary Administrator Checklist.text:
As a Voluntary Administrator, you have the following duties.

Please read each sentence carefully and click each box to agree to do that job:
01a-Voluntary Administrator Checklist.help:
Read each sentence carefully and click each box to agree to do that job.

When you sign the Affidavit, you will be swearing that you will do all of these jobs. The court's form uses words that are hard for people to understand. You should ask the court clerk to explain what you don't understand.

If you do not agree to do these jobs, then you should not use this program. You have to agree in order to be a Voluntary Administrator.

04-Disclaimer.name: 04-Disclaimer
04-Disclaimer.text:
%%[Client first name TE]%%, the only service we can give you is this program, which will help you complete this form.

This program can only give you legal information and not legal advice.

I understand that this program cannot give me legal advice.
04-Disclaimer.learn: What can the court clerk do?
04-Disclaimer.help:
Court clerks cannot apply or interpret the law for you. They cannot make a recommendation of what you should do in your case or situation. They cannot give you legal advice.

The court clerk can only explain court procedure and tell you your options without referring to your specific case or situation.

01-About the distributees.name: 01-About the distributees
01-About the distributees.text:
Now I will ask you some questions about the distributees of %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%.

A distributee is a person who the law says might get some of %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s property.

END IF

1-Done!.name: 1-Done!
1-Done!.text:
Finished

Congratulations! You have finished the program.

If you are at a public computer, remember to close this program and your Small Estate Affidavit before leaving to protect your privacy. If you don't know how, ask someone to help you. It is very important.

2-Congratulations.name: 2-Congratulations
2-Congratulations.text:
To exit the program and get your results, please click Finish (one time), and wait for the next screen to appear.

At the next screen, click Get Document.

When your document is ready, click on Open. You will be able to see and print your affidavit. Then, bring the affidavit to the Surrogate's Court.

1-Asset Intro.learn: What is the legal definition of "assets"?

SET [Client is distributee spouse TF] TO "true"
SET [Client is distributee TF] TO "true"
END IF

IF [Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Son"
SET [Client is distributee TF] TO "true"
END IF

IF [Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Other"
GOTO "07d-Other relationship to the decedent"
END IF

IF [Client relationship to decedent MC] <> "Other"
GOTO "08a-Confirm your relationship"
END IF

08a-Confirm your relationship.name: 08a-Confirm your relationship
08a-Confirm your relationship.text:
You said you are %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s %%[Client relationship to decedent MC]%%.

Is this correct?
08a-Confirm your relationship.codeAfter:
//set decedent has spouse to true if Pet is Wife or Husband
IF [Client relationship start over TF] = "false"
GOTO "07a-Your relationship to the deceased"
END IF

//set decedent has spouse to true if Pet is Wife or Husband
IF ([Client relationship to decedent MC] <>"Wife") and ([Client relationship to decedent MC] <>"Husband")
SET [Decedent has spouse TF] TO "false"
END IF

//set decedent has spouse to true if Pet is Wife or Husband
IF ([Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Son") or ([Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Daughter")
SET [Decedent has children TF] TO "true"
GOTO "09-Non-marital child?"
ELSE
GOTO "01-About the distributees"
END IF
08a-Confirm your relationship.notes: Don't delete this q. it sets the has spouse TF variable

03-Date of death.name: 03-Date of death

Now, I need to make sure that this program is right for you.

What is the date that %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%% died?

(Note: use the arrow keys next to the boxes to find the correct date - MM/DD/YYYY)
03-Date of death.help: You can only use this program if %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%% died after 1996.

fields.label: Date:
fields.name: Decedent date of death DA
fields.invalidPrompt: To use this program, %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%% had to have died after August 29, 1996.

03-Date of death.codeAfter:
SET [Cut off 1996 DA] TO "08/29/1996"
SET [Cut off 2008 DA] TO "12/31/2008"

IF [Decedent date of death DA] < [Cut off 1996 DA]
GOTO "03a-Date of death"
END IF

IF ([Decedent date of death DA] >= [Cut off 1996 DA]) AND ([Decedent date of death DA] <= [Cut off 2008 DA])
SET [Asset limit NU] TO "20000"
SET [SE-3A form TF] TO "false"
GOTO "04a-Decedent place of death"
ELSE
SET [Asset limit NU] TO "30000"
SET [SE-3A form TF] TO "true"
GOTO "04a-Decedent place of death"
END IF

06-Where will you file the affidavit?.text: In what county are you filing this form?
06-Where will you file the affidavit?.help: Usually, you should file the affidavit in the county where the person who died lived, or where most of his or her property is located.

SET [Decedent county TE] TO [Jurisdiction county MC]

1-Liabilities info.name: 1-Liabilities info

%%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s Liabilities

You are almost done. Now I will ask you whether %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%% owed anyone money.

When someone dies, some of the debts he or she owed at death should be paid to people or companies from the property of the estate.

These debts are called liabilities.

You will have a chance to add another creditor.
2a-Who is the first creditor?.help:

Amount: $2,200.00

Details: Account # 1234567890123456

Creditor: Warner Funeral Home

Amount: $2,000.00

Details: for coffin and burial

Creditor: AT&T Wireless

Amount: $75.00

Details: Account # 9175555555

When you swear to this affidavit and give it to the court, you are promising to distribute %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s property according to the law.

5-Exempt assets.name: 5-Exempt assets
5-Exempt assets.text:
Exempt Assets

Paragraph 9 on the Affidavit has boxes to write in

"Items of personal property exempt under EPTL."

You should ask the clerk about exempt property if %%[Decedent first name TE]%% has a spouse, or %%[Decedent first name TE]%% has a child under 21 years old.
5-Exempt assets.learn: Why should I ask the clerk about exempt property?
5-Exempt assets.help: You can use this program and Affidavit if the estate has a value of $%%DOLLAR([Asset limit NU])%%. Some assets don't count toward the $%%DOLLAR([Asset limit NU])%% limit if there is a spouse or child under 21 years of age. These exempt assets can include a computer, a car, and the family bible.

11a-Spouse has priority.name: 11a-Spouse has priority
11a-Spouse has priority.text:
You said that %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%% has a living %%[husband/wife TE]%%, and you are not %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s spouse.

%%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s %%[husband/wife TE]%% has to give up %%[spouse his/her TE]%% right to distribute the estate before you can become the Voluntary Administrator.
11a-Spouse has priority.codeBefore:
//If there is no spouse at all, go on to check 2nd level priority.
IF [Client is distributee spouse TF] = "true"
GOTO "1-Asset Intro"
END IF

//If there is no spouse at all, go on to check 2nd level priority.
IF [Decedent has spouse TF] = "false"
SET [Print renunciation TF] TO "true"
GOTO "11b-Priority - See the Clerk"
ELSE
SET [Print renunciation TF] TO "true"
END IF

11b-Priority - See the Clerk.name: 11b-Priority - See the Clerk
11b-Priority - See the Clerk.text:
You said that %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%% left no will and had no spouse who is alive.

There are complicated rules about who can handle the estate. Basically, it has to be

%%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s closest surviving relative.

You should ask the Court Clerk to make sure that you can file this form to be the Voluntary Administrator.
11b-Priority - See the Clerk.help:
When there is no will, only certain people can apply to be the voluntary administrator.

The closest relative has to be the administrator, unless he or she "renounces" (gives up) the right to administer the estate. For this form, this is the order:

- the spouse,

- any surviving child or grandchild whose parent has died,

- any other grandchildren,

- a parent of %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%,

- %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s brothers or sisters,

- any other people who are "distributees"
11b-Priority - See the Clerk.notes:
If D had children or qgc, and P is not child or qgc... show error

D had will, skip this logic:

If D left live spouse and P is not spouse, see clerk.

If D left children/grandchildren and P is not spouse or child/grandch , see clerk

If D left parent and P is not spouse, child/grandch, or parent, see clerk.

*** we already kick them out if D did not have at least a parent, so don't need logic below this line***

If D left sibling and P is not spouse, child/grandch, parent, or sibling, see clerk.

If D left neice or nephew or aunt or uncle, and P is not one of those or higher in priority, see clerk.

06-LOGIC STEP.name: 06-LOGIC STEP
06-LOGIC STEP.codeBefore:
IF c_count = 1
SET [child/children TE] TO "child"

ELSE

SET [is/are TE] TO "are"
END IF

IF g_count = 1
SET [grandchild/children TE] TO "grandchild"
SET [grandchild is/are TE] TO "is"
SET [child/children2 TE] TO "child"
ELSE
SET [grandchild/children TE] TO "grandchildren"
SET [grandchild is/are TE] TO "are"
SET [child/children2 TE] TO "children"
END IF

IF [Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Son" or [Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Daughter"
SET [Dynamic text TE] TO "Other than you,"
ELSE
SET [Dynamic text TE] TO ""
END IF

IF [c_count]=0 and [g_count]=0
GOTO "06.1-No children and no grandchildren"
END IF

IF [c_count]=0 and [g_count]>0
GOTO "06.2-No children but has grandchildren"
END IF

IF [c_count]>0 and [g_count]=0
GOTO "06.3-Children but no grandchildren"
END IF

IF [c_count]>0 and [g_count]>0

END IF

Checking to see that the asset totals are less than statutory amount.

Limit: $20,000

Date of death: On or after January 1, 2009

Limit: $30,000

END IF

1a-Asset examples.name: 1a-Asset examples
1a-Asset examples.text:
Assets may include the following:

* Checking account

* Savings account

* CDs

* Stocks and bonds

* Savings bonds

* Cars

* Boats

1b-Asset details.name: 1b-Asset details
1b-Asset details.text:
Please include details about the asset.

For example, for each asset include information such as:

* account numbers

* vehicle VIN numbers

* serial numbers

1a-Liabilities info.name: 1a-Liabilities info
1a-Liabilities info.text:
Liabilities may include the following:

* Credit card bills

* Funeral expenses

* Medical expenses

* Unpaid bills

* Loans

* Income tax

05-Filing fee.name: 05-Filing fee
05-Filing fee.text:
When you finish this program, you will be able to print Instructions and the Small Estate Affidavit.

You must file this in the Surrogate's Court in the county where the person who died lived.

The filing fee for the Small Estate Affidavit is $1.00.

07b-Real property issue.name: 07b-Real property issue
07b-Real property issue.text:
You can use this program only if you are administering the %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s personal property.

Personal property includes assets such as bank accounts, investment accounts, cars, boats and other personal belongings.

If %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s house or land is going to be sold, you cannot use this program. Please contact your Surrogate's Court for more information.

01b-Voluntary Administrator Checklist.name: 01b-Voluntary Administrator Checklist
01b-Voluntary Administrator Checklist.text: Your duties as a Voluntary Administrator (continued):
01b-Voluntary Administrator Checklist.help:
Read each sentence carefully and click each box to agree to do that job.

When you sign the Affidavit, you will be swearing that you will do all of these jobs. The court's form uses words that are hard for people to understand. You should ask the court clerk to explain what you don't understand.

If you do not agree to do these jobs, then you should not use this program. You have to agree in order to be a Voluntary Administrator.

4-Estate account.name: 4-Estate account
4-Estate account.text:
As voluntary administrator, you will have to open an estate bank account in %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s name.

Your printed Small Estate Affidavit will ask for a certificate of letters to open an estate account.
4-Estate account.learn: Why do I have to open an estate bank account?
4-Estate account.help:
As a voluntary administrator, you have a duty to %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s estate to keep all the estate funds in a safe place.

An estate bank account is where you will deposit estate funds as well as pay off estate expenses.

3-Unclaimed funds.name: 3-Unclaimed funds
3-Unclaimed funds.text:
%%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%% may have unclaimed funds in New York State.

Would you like to request permission to obtain information as to the value of any of %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s unclaimed funds from the NYS Comptroller?
3-Unclaimed funds.help:
Did you ever...

* Move without notifying everyone with whom you do business of your new address?

* Open a school savings account as a child or for your own child and then forget about it?

* Move without getting your utility deposit refund?

* Forget to cash a health insurance check?

* Neglect to cash interest or dividend checks on a security?

* Leave a job and never go back to get your last paycheck?

In cases like these, your money is eventually turned over to the State.

State law requires banks, insurance companies, utilities, and other businesses to turn dormant savings accounts, unclaimed insurance and stock dividends, and other inactive holdings over to the State.

If there has been no activity in the account for a set period of time, usually between two and five years, your money is considered unclaimed or abandoned.

ELSE
GOTO "4-Estate account"

1-Non-monetary certificates.text:
Certificate of letters

The purpose of a certificate of letters is to give proof that the Surrogate's Court has authorized you to deal with %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s affairs and property.

Depending on your situation, you may need additional certificates of letters to obtain %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s medical records or information about any unclaimed funds in %%[Decedent first name TE]%% %%[Decedent last name TE]%%'s name.

03-Instructions.name: 03-Instructions
03-Instructions.text:
How to Use This Program

You can click on any word that is in RED for a definition. You can also click on "Learn More" for more information.

Please do not use the Back button (the button with the green arrow in the top left hand corner of this screen) during the program.

The courthouse picture will get closer as you answer questions.
03-Instructions.help: If you click on "Learn More" you get information that helps you answer the question.

04a-Non-marital child?.text: Is %%[Child first name TE#c_count]%% %%[Child last name TE#c_count]%% a non-marital child?
04a-Non-marital child?.help: This means that the child's parents were not married to each other at the time of birth.

09-Non-marital child?.text: Are you a non-marital child?
09-Non-marital child?.help: This means that your parents were not married to each other at the time of your birth.

IF [Client relationship start over TF] = "false"
GOTO "07a-Your relationship to the deceased"
END IF

//set decedent has spouse to true if Pet is Wife or Husband
IF ([Client relationship to decedent MC] <>"Wife") and ([Client relationship to decedent MC] <>"Husband")
SET [Decedent has spouse TF] TO "false"
END IF

//set decedent has spouse to true if Pet is Wife or Husband
IF ([Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Son") or ([Client relationship to decedent MC] = "Daughter")
SET [Decedent has children TF] TO "true"
GOTO "09-Non-marital child?"
ELSE
GOTO "01-About the distributees"
END IF

01-Introduction popup.name: 01-Introduction popup
01-Introduction popup.text:
The Small Estate Affidavit is also known as the Affidavit of Voluntary Administration.

By filing this form, you are volunteering to become the Voluntary Administrator. As Voluntary Administrator you will administer (divide) the deceased's property. With this Affidavit of Voluntary Administration you swear to facts that the Court uses to decide if you are the right person to administer the property of the person who died. The Court makes sure that the property of the person who died is divided correctly, according to the law.

01-Decedent Full Name popup.name: 01-Decedent Full Name popup
01-Decedent Full Name popup.text: The "decedent" is the legal word used for the person who died.

01a-Voluntary Administrator Checklist po.name: 01a-Voluntary Administrator Checklist popup
01a-Voluntary Administrator Checklist po.text:
By filing the small estate affidavit, you are asking the Surrogate's Court to appoint you as the voluntary administrator.

A voluntary administrator disposes of the assets of a person who died. The voluntary administrator is not paid.

04-Disclaimer popup.name: 04-Disclaimer popup
04-Disclaimer popup.text: Legal information includes information about court procedures, court rules, definitions of legal terms, and information about available resources.

04-Disclaimer popup 2.name: 04-Disclaimer popup 2
04-Disclaimer popup 2.text: Legal advice includes application of the law to your specific case and telling you whether or not you should do something.

2a-What is the first asset? popup.text:

* Checking account

* Savings account

* CDs

* Stocks and bonds

* Savings bonds

* Cars

* Boats

09-Non-marital child? popup.name: 09-Non-marital child? popup
09-Non-marital child? popup.text:
A non-marital child is a child who was born out of wedlock.

This means that your parents were not married at the time of your birth.
